--- Tyler Streeter <tylerstreeter@...> wrote:
> * joint angles
> * joint velocities
> * body part positions (global coordinates or maybe
> offset from the center of mass)
> * overall center of mass
> * forces on body parts
> 
> They need to have enough information to be able to
> perform a complex sequence of actions (e.g.
> walking). 
> Any thought on these ideas for inputs or have other
> ideas?  Do you think some are more or less
> important?

Hey Tyler. :)

These inputs are all good, and I would personally
think they'd all be important.  But unless the agent
is always going to be walking in a predictable,
uniform environment (which I assume it is not),
there's going to need to be some form of input
describing the external environment.  Your agent is
effectively blind and deaf, and could probably be
trained to move across an even surface, but locomotion
requires information about the path ahead, or else
it's going to walk off cliffs and fall down a lot.

I'd also be more concerned about your fitness function
with complex behaviors like walking (or jumping
without falling down).  With jumping and standing,
you're simply using the average vertical position of
the head over time to determine fitness...is this
correct?

And with walking, are you simply measuring movement in
a given horizontal direction?

How hard is it to manually program one of your agents
to walk or jump?  Have you done this?  If so, it might
be interesting to evolve neural network controllers
that best mimic the movements of the preprogrammed
ones, to at least give them a certain level of
proficiency that can then be built upon.

Or, with walking, you could take the approach humans
use.  The fitness function could be a result of
horizontal movement, while keeping the center of mass
within a given range.  Agents that fall down could be
"picked back up", just as human infants are, so that a
given fitness evaluation is not necessarily over once
the agent falls down.

Anyway...just some suggestions.  It's a cool domain,
and I look forward to seeing how it comes along, and
maybe playing around with it a bit as well.

Derek
